docs.title: API Credential Documentation
docs.text: Welcome to the API Credential service documentation. This documentation provides comprehensive information about the API Credential service, its features, and how to use it.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The API Credential service is a part of the Karned Kommon platform that handles authentication and authorization for API access. It provides secure credential management and access control for various services.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Secure credential storage and management
  • Token-based authentication
  • Permission-based access control
  • Rate limiting and throttling
  • Audit logging

docs.title: Quick Links
docs.text:
• Getting Started - Learn how to set up and start using the API Credential service
  • API Reference - Detailed information about the API endpoints
  • Development - Information for developers who want to contribute to the project

docs.title: Support
docs.text: If you need help or have questions, please contact the Karned team.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with the API Credential service.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have the following:

  • Python 3.8 or higher
  • Docker (optional, for containerized deployment)
  • Access to the Karned platform

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/Karned/Kommon/api-credential.git
cd api-credential

  2. Create a virtual environment and activate it: 

    python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # On Windows, use: .venv\Scripts\activate

  3. Install dependencies: 

    pip install -r requirements.txt

  4. Run the application: 

    uvicorn main:app --reload

The API will be available at http://localhost:8000.

docs.title: Docker Deployment
docs.text:
1. Build the Docker image: 

    docker build -t api-credential .

  2. Run the container: 

    docker run -p 8000:8000 api-credential

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: The API Credential service can be configured using environment variables or a configuration file. See the configuration documentation for more details.

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: To authenticate with the API, you need to obtain an API token. See the authentication documentation for more details.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Explore the API Reference to learn about the available endpoints
  • Learn about development and contributing to the project

docs.title: API Endpoints
docs.text: This page documents all available endpoints in the API Credential service.

docs.title: Get Token
docs.text:
POST /v1/token

Generates a new authentication token.

Request Body:

{
  "username": "string",
  "password": "string"
}

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "token": "string",
    "expires_at": "datetime",
    "token_type": "bearer"
  }
}

docs.title: Refresh Token
docs.text:
POST /v1/token/refresh

Refreshes an existing authentication token.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "token": "string",
    "expires_at": "datetime",
    "token_type": "bearer"
  }
}

docs.title: Revoke Token
docs.text:
POST /v1/token/revoke

Revokes an existing authentication token.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "message": "Token revoked successfully"
}

docs.title: List Credentials
docs.text:
GET /v1/credentials

Returns a list of all credentials for the authenticated user.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "credentials": [
      {
        "id": "string",
        "name": "string",
        "type": "string",
        "created_at": "datetime",
        "last_used": "datetime"
      }
    ]
  }
}

docs.title: Create Credential
docs.text:
POST /v1/credentials

Creates a new credential.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Request Body:

{
  "name": "string",
  "type": "string",
  "permissions": ["string"]
}

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "credential": {
      "id": "string",
      "name": "string",
      "type": "string",
      "key": "string",
      "created_at": "datetime"
    }
  },
  "message": "Credential created successfully"
}

docs.title: Get Credential
docs.text:
GET /v1/credentials/{credential_id}

Returns details for a specific credential.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "credential": {
      "id": "string",
      "name": "string",
      "type": "string",
      "created_at": "datetime",
      "last_used": "datetime",
      "permissions": ["string"]
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Update Credential
docs.text:
PUT /v1/credentials/{credential_id}

Updates an existing credential.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Request Body:

{
  "name": "string",
  "permissions": ["string"]
}

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "credential": {
      "id": "string",
      "name": "string",
      "type": "string",
      "created_at": "datetime",
      "updated_at": "datetime"
    }
  },
  "message": "Credential updated successfully"
}

docs.title: Delete Credential
docs.text:
DELETE /v1/credentials/{credential_id}

Deletes an existing credential.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "message": "Credential deleted successfully"
}

docs.title: List Permissions
docs.text:
GET /v1/permissions

Returns a list of all available permissions.

Request Headers:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "permissions": [
      {
        "id": "string",
        "name": "string",
        "description": "string"
      }
    ]
  }
}

docs.title: Health Check
docs.text:
GET /health

Returns the health status of the API.

Response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "status": "healthy",
    "version": "string",
    "uptime": "string"
  }
}

docs.title: API Reference Overview
docs.text: This section provides detailed information about the API Credential service endpoints, authentication methods, and response formats.

docs.title: Base URL
docs.text:
The base URL for all API endpoints is:

https://api.karned.com/credential/

For local development, the base URL is:

http://localhost:8000/

docs.title: API Versions
docs.text:
The API Credential service supports multiple API versions:

  • v0: Legacy API (deprecated)
  • v1: Current stable API

To specify the API version, include it in the URL path:

https://api.karned.com/credential/v1/

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: All API endpoints require authentication. The API Credential service supports the following authentication methods:

docs.title: Token Authentication
docs.text:
Most endpoints require a token in the Authorization header:

Authorization: Bearer <your_token>

docs.title: API Key Authentication
docs.text:
Some endpoints support API key authentication. Include the API key in the X-API-Key header:

X-API-Key: <your_api_key>

docs.title: Response Format
docs.text:
All API responses are in JSON format. A typical response has the following structure:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    // Response data
  },
  "message": "Operation completed successfully"
}

docs.title: Error Responses
docs.text:
Error responses have the following structure:

{
  "status": "error",
  "error": {
    "code": "ERROR_CODE",
    "message": "Error message"
  }
}

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text:
The API has rate limiting to prevent abuse. The current limits are:

  • 100 requests per minute for authenticated users
  • 10 requests per minute for unauthenticated users

Rate limit information is included in the response headers:

  • X-RateLimit-Limit: The maximum number of requests allowed per minute
  • X-RateLimit-Remaining: The number of requests remaining in the current time window
  • X-RateLimit-Reset: The time when the rate limit will reset (Unix timestamp)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Explore the Endpoints documentation for detailed information about each API endpoint.

docs.title: Contributing Guidelines
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the API Credential service! This document provides guidelines and instructions for contributing to the project.

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text: Please read and follow our Code of Conduct to foster an inclusive and respectful community.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository on GitHub
  2. Clone your fork locally
  3. Set up the development environment as described in the Setup Guide
  4. Create a new branch for your feature or bug fix

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Create a new branch from main for your changes 

    git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

  2. Make your changes and ensure they follow the project's coding standards

  3. Write or update tests for your changes

  4. Run the tests to ensure they pass 

    pytest

  5. Format your code 

    black .
isort .

  6. Commit your changes with a descriptive commit message 

    git commit -m "Add feature: your feature description"

  7. Push your branch to your fork 

    git push origin feature/your-feature-name

  8. Create a pull request from your fork to the main repository

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
When submitting a pull request, please ensure:

  1. Your code follows the project's coding standards
  2. All tests pass
  3. Your changes are well-documented
  4. Your pull request has a descriptive title and detailed description
  5. Your pull request addresses only one issue or adds one feature

docs.title: Coding Standards
docs.text:
• Follow PEP 8 style guidelines
  • Use type hints for function parameters and return values
  • Write docstrings for all functions, classes, and modules
  • Keep functions small and focused on a single responsibility
  • Use meaningful variable and function names

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
• Write unit tests for all new functionality
  • Ensure all tests pass before submitting a pull request
  • Aim for high test coverage

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
• Update documentation for any changes to the API or functionality
  • Document all new features, endpoints, and configuration options
  • Keep the README and other documentation up to date

docs.title: Versioning
docs.text:
We follow Semantic Versioning for this project:

  • MAJOR version for incompatible API changes
  • MINOR version for new functionality in a backward-compatible manner
  • PATCH version for backward-compatible bug fixes

docs.title: Issue Reporting
docs.text:
If you find a bug or have a feature request, please create an issue on GitHub:

  1. Check if the issue already exists
  2. Use a clear and descriptive title
  3. Provide detailed steps to reproduce the issue
  4. Include relevant logs, error messages, and screenshots
  5. Describe the expected behavior and the actual behavior

docs.title: Code Review Process
docs.text:
All submissions require review. We use GitHub pull requests for this purpose:

  1. A maintainer will review your pull request
  2. They may request changes or improvements
  3. Once approved, a maintainer will merge your pull request

docs.title: License
docs.text: By contributing to this project, you agree that your contributions will be licensed under the project's LICENSE.

docs.title: Questions?
docs.text:
If you have any questions or need help, please reach out to the maintainers or create an issue on GitHub.

Thank you for contributing to the API Credential service!

docs.title: Deploying to GitHub Pages
docs.text: This guide explains how to deploy the API Credential documentation to GitHub Pages.

docs.title: Automatic Deployment
docs.text: The documentation is automatically deployed to GitHub Pages whenever changes are pushed to the main branch that modify files in the docs/ directory or the mkdocs.yml file. This is handled by a GitHub Actions workflow.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. The GitHub Actions workflow is defined in .github/workflows/deploy-docs.yml
  2. When changes are pushed to the main branch, the workflow:
  3. Sets up a Python environment
  4. Installs MkDocs and required dependencies
  5. Builds the documentation
  6. Deploys it to the gh-pages branch
  7. GitHub Pages serves the content from the gh-pages branch

docs.title: Viewing the Deployment Status
docs.text: You can check the status of the deployment in the "Actions" tab of the GitHub repository.

docs.title: Manual Deployment
docs.text: If you need to deploy the documentation manually, you can do so using the MkDocs gh-deploy command.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.8 or higher
  • MkDocs and required dependencies installed

docs.title: Deployment Steps
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/Karned/Kommon/api-credential.git
cd api-credential

  2. Install the required dependencies: 

    pip install -r requirements.txt

  3. Deploy to GitHub Pages: 

    mkdocs gh-deploy

This command builds the documentation and pushes it to the gh-pages branch of the repository.

docs.title: Forcing Deployment
docs.text:
If you need to force the deployment (overwriting existing content), use:

mkdocs gh-deploy --force

docs.title: Accessing the Documentation
docs.text:
Once deployed, the documentation is available at:

https://karned.github.io/Kommon/api-credential/

docs.title: Documentation Not Updating
docs.text:
If the documentation is not updating after a push:

  1. Check the GitHub Actions workflow in the "Actions" tab
  2. Ensure the repository has GitHub Pages enabled in the repository settings
  3. Verify that the GitHub Pages source is set to the gh-pages branch

docs.title: Local Testing
docs.text:
To test the documentation locally before deployment:

mkdocs serve

This starts a local server at http://localhost:8000 where you can preview the documentation.

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text: This guide provides instructions for setting up a development environment for the API Credential service.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, make sure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.8 or higher
  • Git
  • Docker (optional, for containerized development)
  • Redis (for caching and session management)

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/Karned/Kommon/api-credential.git
cd api-credential

docs.title: Virtual Environment
docs.text:
It's recommended to use a virtual environment for development:

python -m venv .venv
source .venv/bin/activate  # On Windows, use: .venv\Scripts\activate

docs.title: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Install the required dependencies:

pip install -r requirements.txt

For development, you may also want to install additional packages:

pip install pytest pytest-cov black isort flake8

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
The API Credential service uses environment variables for configuration. Create a .env file in the root directory with the following variables:

# API Configuration
API_HOST=0.0.0.0
API_PORT=8000
DEBUG=True
ENVIRONMENT=development

# Security
SECRET_KEY=your_secret_key_here
TOKEN_EXPIRATION=86400  # 24 hours in seconds

# Redis Configuration
REDIS_HOST=localhost
REDIS_PORT=6379
REDIS_DB=0
REDIS_PASSWORD=

# Logging
LOG_LEVEL=DEBUG

docs.title: Database Setup
docs.text:
The API Credential service uses Redis for caching and session management. Make sure Redis is running:

# Start Redis using Docker
docker run --name redis -p 6379:6379 -d redis

# Or if you have Redis installed locally
redis-server

docs.title: Running the Application
docs.text:
Start the application in development mode:

uvicorn main:app --reload --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000

The API will be available at http://localhost:8000.

docs.title: API Documentation
docs.text: The API documentation is available at http://localhost:8000/docs when the application is running.

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
Run the tests using pytest:

pytest

To generate a coverage report:

pytest --cov=.

docs.title: Code Formatting
docs.text:
Format your code using Black and isort:

black .
isort .

Check for linting issues:

flake8

docs.title: Debugging
docs.text:
For debugging, you can use the built-in debugger in your IDE or the Python debugger (pdb).

To use pdb, add the following line where you want to set a breakpoint:

import pdb; pdb.set_trace()

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
The project documentation is built using MkDocs. To build and serve the documentation locally:

mkdocs serve

The documentation will be available at http://localhost:8000.
